journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Modelling the power parameters of the spherical motion burnishing

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Technical University of Gabrovo, 5300 Gabrovo, Bulgaria. email: jordanmaximov@abv.bg

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: This article presents the outcomes from analytical and experimental modelling, the power parameters of new burnishing of external cylindrical surfaces called spherical motion burnishing. The axes of the workpiece and the ring-shaped tool having toroidal acting surface intersect at an angle of 2°. The tool motion is superposition from a spherical motion and a rectilinear translation with respect to the workpiece. The method is implemented on lathes. The tool transfer angular velocity is assigned by the lathe spindle, and the relative one is a consequence from unknown manufacturing resistance. Analytical models of the power parameters of the new burnishing process have been obtained. The unknown manufacturing intensities in these models have been determined experimentally. For proving the authenticity of the proposed semi-analytical models a comparison of the results obtained for the axial force with the experimental ones has been made. For that purpose, the axial force has been measured by means of a strain gauge system. The comparison shows a good agreement.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In the process of operation shafts and rotating axles are subject to dynamic, and in particular, cyclic loads, which determines the fatigue of materials as a limiting factor for their service. It is a well known fact that fatigue failure is caused by the growth of cracks, most frequently appearing in the superficial layer [1] which, on the one hand, is a carrier of manufacturing and natural concentrators, and on the other hand, the operating stresses arising there have maximum absolute values. Therefore, mechanical surface treatment of machine elements is of decisive importance since both micro-geometry (roughness, wave-likeness, marks, and traces from the working) and physical and mechanical state (residual stresses, micro-hardness,and structure) of the superficial layer depend on it.

A number of authors [1–6] have agreed on the fact that the generation of a residual compressive stress field in the superficial layer of the metal structural components considerably enhances their fatigue life. In this aspect, the methods of mechanical surface treatment whose basic concept is a localized near-surface plastic deformation are very promising. Some of the best known methods of mechanical surface treatment of external cylindrical surfaces classified by Suchkov [3] are: ball burnishing; roller burnishing; deep rolling; and diamond burnishing.

These can significantly improve surface quality and further enhance fatigue life and load carrying capacity of the corresponding machine element. A careful study of diamond burnishing regarding the quality of the surface treated and fatigue life was carried out byYatzenko [4]. Jujerm and Altenberger [5] demonstrated the effectiveness of the deep rolling process for enhancement of the fatigue life of cylindrical specimens made of austenitic stainless steel AISI 304 andnormalized plain carbon steel SAE 1045 in the conditions of high cycle fatigue regime. Zhang and Lindemann [6] investigated the effect of applying roller burnishing to high cycle fatigue strength of wrought magnesium alloy AZ80. They found the optimal rolling force and achieved improvement of fatigue strength by about 110 per cent. A comprehensive study of ball and roller burnishing and the influence of the quality of the surface treatment on the fatigue life of the corresponding structural component has been carried out by Suchkov [3]. Significant research work in the field of burnishing technology has been carried out by Ecoroll, Germany as well as at the laboratory WZL/RWTH, Aachen, Germany [7].

Regardless of the numerous investigations that have been made so far the efforts of the researchers are directed to extension of the potentials of the burnishing process towards enhancement of depth hardening, decrease of surface roughness, increase of dimensional accuracy, treatment of hard materials, and so on, by means of creating new hybrid burnishing methods, new burnishing tools, deforming coated rollers, developing of analytical, and finite element (FE)B models for analysis and optimization of that process. A novel laser assisted burnishing method applied to hard materials is developed by Tian and Shin [8] and isstudied experimentally. This method produces much better surface quality, greater surface hardness, and similar compressive residual stresses in comparison with the conventional burnishing. Shiou and Ciou [9] introduced a new vibration-assisted spherical polishing system to improve the burnished surface roughness of hardened stainless mold steel. Aroughness of Ra = 0.045 μm is achieved. Bozdana et al. [10] developed a new ultrasonic deep rolling technique for treating thin components. El-Tayeb etal. [11] introduced a new burnishing tool with interchangeable adapter for ball and roller. They found out that the decrease in the contact width between the roller and the workpiece leads to a decrease in the surface roughness. El-Axir and Ibrahim [12] developed a new burnishing tool for treatment of external cylindrical surfaces. The center rest of a lathe is used as a ball burnishing tool. The quality of the burnished surfaces is improved as a result of using this tool. Yeldose and Ramamoorthy [13] demonstrated the benefit from using TiN-coated rollers in the burnishing process. An analytical model of the smoothing ball burnishing was proposed by Korzynski [14] with the purpose of optimizing of the burnishing process. Yen et al. [15] developed finite element models of hard roller burnishing with the purpose of fundamental understanding the process mechanics and in particular to predict residual stresses.

On the basis of the analysis of the existing methods, a new method [16] of mechanical surface treatment of machine elements such as shafts and axles has been synthesized and it is referred to as ‘spherical motion burnishing’ (SMB). Characteristic feature of the SMB method is its specific kinemathics, which is described in section 2.1. The axes of the workpiece and ring-shaped tool, having internal toroidal acting surface intersect at small angle θ (Fig. 1). The tool motion is superposition from a spherical motion and a rectilinear translation with respect to the workpiece. The contact between the surface treated and its enveloped tool acting surface is sliding friction in the presence of lubricant. The method is implemented on conventional machine tools, in particular, on lathes by means of a relatively simple device and tool. The SMB can be classified as mixed burnishing because it combines the advantages of hardening, dimensional, and smoothing burnishing according to the classification made by Korzynski [17]. Fig. 1
SMB method implementation on lathes: (a) conventional lathes; (b) CNC lathes; (c) device scheme for SMB method

The dependence of the manufacturing resistance on the process parameters has been of substantial interest because of the special feature of the developed method. The presence of this dependence is a necessary condition for the process of optimization. Surface distributed load by which the workpiece acts to the tool represents the manufacturing resistance. Itis a consequence of elastic and plastic deformation (stress flow) of the material treated as well as of the sliding friction (mechanical, adhesion) on the contact surface between the tool and the workpiece.

On the other hand, a correlation between the manufacturing resistance and the power parameter (rotating moment Me (Fig. 1), applied on the machine spindle; axial force Pa, applied on the tool) of the SMB process exists.
The main objective of this study is to develop a mathematical model of the power parameters Me and Pa of the SMB process.

sec.title: 2.1 Implementation on lathes
sec.p: The SMB method is carried out on lathes (Fig. 1) by means of a relatively simple device and tool and has a capacity for treatment of relatively long workpieces. The axes of the tool and of the workpiece intersect at angle θ of 2°. The tool, positioned on radial and axial bearings in the body, rotates around its own axis at angular velocity ω→t and the workpiece being formed rotates around its own axis at angular velocity ω→w. The angle between the vectors of the two angular velocities is equal to θ and simultaneously the tool moves along the workpiece axis at translational velocity ν→f.

Sliding friction contact arises between the tool and the workpiece. Each point from the equator of the tool acting part moves along ‘extended’, respectively, ‘shortened’ spherical curve with respect to a coordinate system joined to the workpiece. The type of the trajectory indicates that the metal bit from the workpiece surface changes the direction of its relative velocity along the current line tool-workpiece at least twice depending on the velocity ν→f. This specific kinematics allows the formation of a natural hydrodynamic wedge of the lubricant between the tool and the workpiece. As a result, there is no abrasion on theworked surface. The method kinematics allows implementing on lathes, by a relatively small axial force. The line diagram of the method corresponds to forming by generating method with continuous contact in cross-section between the toroidal acting surface of the tool and the workpiece under sliding friction and lubrication conditions.

sec.title: 2.2 The problem of the actual spherical tool motion
sec.p: If angular velocity –ω→w is mentally imparted to ‘tool-workpiece’ system (Fig. 1(b)) the workpiece will be static and the tool will perform spherical motion with constant angle of nutation θ and rectilinear translation. Accordinaly, the tool will rotate around the workpiece axis at transfer angular velocity ω→e=–ω→w and around its own axis at relative angular velocity ω→r=–ω→t. The transfer angular velocity is assigned by the machine spindle, and the relative angular velocity is determined by the active and the resisting forces of plastic deformation and friction applied to the tool. The distribution law and the intensity of these resisting forces are unknown and, therefore, the relative angular velocity, respectively, the real spherical tool motion, cannot be found by the deferential equations of the tool motion. For this reason, it is necessary to use a variational approach. Awareness of the real spherical motion is a necessary condition for analytical modelling of the power parameters Me and Pa of the SMB process.

Applying the approach developed by Maximov [18] and applied by Maximov and Duncheva [19] to the spherical mandrelling, it has been found out by the authors that the instantaneous axis of rotating in thespherical motion of the tool in a coordinate system related to the workpiece, is perpendicular to the tool axis. In this way, the actual spherical tool motion has been identified out of an infinite set of possible spherical motions.

sec.title: 3 SEMI-ANALYTICAL APPROACH TO MODELLING POWER PARAMETERS
3.1 Analytical modelling of the axial force and the rotating moment
3.1.1 Tool kinematic screw
sec.p:
The tool performs a superposition from spherical motion at absolute angular velocity ω→a and rectilinear translation along to the workpiece axis at velocity ν→f and ≺(ω→a,ν→f)=90°±θ° (Fig. 2). Since the motion is uniform, and for the sake of precision, the moment considered when the instantaneous axis of rotation (IAR) in the tool spherical motion lies on the axis Oy′ from the moving coordinate system connected with the tool. The absolute tool motion can be presented as an instantaneous screw motion at angular velocity ω→a around instantaneous screw axis (ISA) at sliding velocity ν→f∗ Fig. 2
A scheme for determination of the manufacturing resistance
ISA lies in the plane Ox′y′ and in the considered moment has the following equation in this plane
Thus, the tool equator is divided into two zones determined by their arcs A1BC1 and C1DA1, which rotate around the axis Oz′ at the transfer angular velocity ω→e.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Analytical models
sec.p: The ISA from the tool kinematic screw lies in the plane Ox′y′. Contact point set (CPS) between the tool and the workpiece is a part from toroidal surface having symmetry axis Oz′. The manufacturing resistance is surface distributed load on the CPS related to the tool. This load is reduced to the tool equator. The projection along the axis Oz′ of the intensity of the manufacturing resistance reduced to the equator from the arc A1DC1 is marked by q1. Similary, the projection against the axis of the intensity from the arc A1DC1 is marked by q2. The angle between q→1 and the tool velocity ν→f is ≺(q→1,ν→f)=θ° and the angle between q→2 and ν→f is ≺(q→2,ν→f)=90°+θ°. Since q→2 is the intensity of the manufacturing resistance resulting only from the elastic workpiece strains, the following dependence is valid: q1 > q2.

The resultant forces of the two distributed loads are, respectively, Q→1 and Q→2 and they lie in a plane, which contains the tool axis (3)
where dt is the tool equator diameter and

The resulting forces Q→i,i=1,2 are reduced to thetool centre point O as a main force vector Q→ and a main moment M→a. Their values are, respectively, (5)
(6)
where xci′ are the centres of gravity of the non-homogeneous arcs A1DC1 and A1BC1.

The vector M→a is perpendicular to the tool axis and it rotates around this axis at the transfer angular velocity ω→e. The SMB power parameters Me and Pa are bound with Q→ and M→a in the following way: the magnitude of the axial force P→a is equal to the magnitude of the projection of the main force vector Q→ on the workpiece axis OZ
The magnitude of the rotating moment M→e is equal to the magnitude of the projection of the main moment M→a on the workpiece axis OZ

In order to determine experimentally the unknown intensities q→i of the manufacturing resistance, it is assumed that they are constant on the corresponding arcs. The physical reasons are the following:

list-item.p: because of the small angle θ the tightness between the tool and the workpiece for each of the arcs is practically constant;
because of the small velocities of the points from the tool equator the influence of the velocity of strain is practically negligible.

sec.p:
The average values of the functions (average specific manufacturing resistances) q1 and q2 are (9)
as the sign ‘+’ corresponds to i = 1.

The coordinates xci′ of the centres of gravity of the non-homogeneous arcs A1DC1 and A1BC1 are (10)
as the sign ‘+’ corresponds to i = 1.

Taking into account (5), (7) and (9) (11)
is obtained for the axial force magnitude.

From equations (6), (8) and (10) (12)
is obtained for the rotating moment magnitude.
On the basis of equations (11) and (12), the following conclusions are made:

list-item.p: The rotating moment Me is over one order smaller than the main moment Ma since the angle of nutation θ is equal to 2°;
The axial force is at least two times smaller compared with the case when the tool perfoms only a translation and its axis coincides with that of the workpiece.

sec.p: Relationships (11) and (12) are analytical models of the axial force and moment of rotating. When the averaged intensities q¯1 and q¯2 are experimentally determined for a certain material as a function of the respective parameters of the process and then are substituted in equations (11) and (12), the desired semi-analytical relationships are obtained.

sec.title: 3.2 Experimental determination of the approximated intensities
3.2.1 Formulation of the study
sec.p: Based on the following characteristics of the deformation process, it is possible to draw the formulation of the experimental study:

list-item.p: In view of the presence of a spherical motion a bigger part of the toroidal acting surface of the tool deforms untreated surface of the workpiece and the other part deforms the already burnished surface overcoming only the elastic deformations. The two zones rotate around the workpiece axis at transfer angular velocity ω→e and at the same time they move along this axis at velocity ν→f
Because of the small angle of nutation θ the tightness between the tool and the workpiece in each zone is practically constant;
Because of the small velocities of the points from the tool equator the influence of the strain velocity tensor is practically negligible.

sec.p: The highlighted moments of the deformation process give reason for the following assumption. The complex deformation process can be rendered as a superposition from two consecutively running in time processes carried out by means of a translationally moving tool. It deforms an untreated zone and once more deforms the already burnished surface of the workpiece. In this way, the determination of theaverage intensities is reduced to experimental determination of the necessary axial (pushing) forces F→i, i = 1 ,2 for each of the two deformation processes and a following devision of the magnitude of this forces by the length of the equator circumference of the tool. After substitution of the approximated intensities q¯i of the manufacturing resistance determined in this way in equations (11) and (12), the power parameters Me and Pa of the SMB process will obtain quantitative definiteness.

sec.title: Objective functions
sec.p: The objective functions Yq¯i, i = 1 ,2 are the magnitudes of the intensities q¯i of the average manufacturing resistance, respectively, for the straight motion (i = 1) and for reverse motion (i = 2). The axial forces Fi during the straight and reverse motions of the tool are measured and the tool performs only straight-line translation. Objective functions Yq¯i are obtained after dividing the maximum measured values of Fi by the length of the equatorial circumference of the tool
Since the axial forces Fi are functions of the parameters of the studied process, having in mind (13) and the objective functions Yq¯i have the same properties as Fi.

sec.title: Governing factors
sec.p: The governing factors are: σY ,MPa is the yield limit of the burnished materials; r¯=r/dt is the dimensionless radius of the toroidal working surface of the tool, where r is the radius of this surface; εt,0=D0–dtD0=indt+in is the nominal circumferential linear strain for the points from the surface burnished, where D0 is the initial diameter before SMB and in is the nominal tightness (double depth of penetration).

Since the intensities q¯i are obtained as a ratio of the axial force measured Fi and the length of the tool equator circumference the diameter dt is not an independent factor. The nominal diameter of the tool is dt = 20 mm.

sec.title: Plan of the experiment
sec.p:
A planned experiment of the type 23 is chosen. The varying levels of the governing factors are shown in Table 1. The factors measured in natural physical units are marked with x˜i. During the experiment each of the factors x˜i alters in a given interval x˜i,min⁡≤x˜i≤x˜i,max⁡. The lower limit x˜i,min⁡ of this interval is called lower level, the upper one x˜i,max⁡ is upper level and the middle x˜i,0 of this interval isthefactor’s basic level. The used factors in the experiment have different dimensions. In order to eliminate the experimental plan’s dependence from the dimensions, the factors x˜i are transformed into a coded form xi through dependence Table 1.
Governing factors and their levels
Governing factors Levels of the factors
Coded (Dimensionless)
−1 +1
Natural x˜i Coded xi Natural (Dimensional)
Yield limit σY [MPa] , x˜1 x1 333 491
Dimensionless radius r¯,x˜2 x2 0.25 0.5
Circumferential strain εt, 0, x˜3 x3 0.005 0.012
The reverse transformation (from coded form xi to measurements in natural units x˜i) is
All coded factors are dimensionless and alter in the same limits: −1 Ĳ xi Ĳ +1,i=1, 2, 3.

sec.title: Material and size of specimens
sec.p: Two kinds of , low- and medium-carbon, having yield limits, σY = 333 MPa and σY = 491 MPa, have been used to make the specimens. Each specimen has nominal length of 50 mm. Three specimens are used for each point from the factor space, respectively, 24 specimens in total. The deviation of the diametral size of each group of specimens is ± 0.01 mm. In terms of size the specimen diameters of each group satisfy parameter εt, 0. The initial roughness is Rainit≈4μm. Special lubricant between the tool and the specimens is used.

sec.title: Experimental equipment
sec.p:
An experimental set-up has been arranged to measure axial forces Fi in real time on universal testing machine ZD 10/90 (Fig. 3). The signal coming from the testing machine is produced by a potentiometer. The axis of the latter is mechanically connected to the display axis of the testing machine. The proportional signal obtained from the pointer displacement is rectified and enters a data acquisition (DAQ) circuit board. It serves to condition the signal and to convert it into a digital one. A virtual tool has been made which processes and stores the data coming into the personal computer. Fig. 3
Measurement of axial forces Fi on universal testing machine ZD 10/90

The measured axial force Fi is a function of the tool displacement. This force Fi has minimum at the beginning and at the end of the motion and has maximum value max Fi around the middle of the motion. The value max Fi is the object of measurement. Each sample passes through the respective tool and the axial force is exerted twice: max F1 is obtained from the first motion and max F2 is obtained from the second motion. After that the intensities q¯i, respectively, the objective functions Yq¯i are calculated by equation (13).

sec.title: 3.2.3 Experimental outcomes
sec.p:
Extended experimental design matrix is shown in Table 2, where F1 and F2 are maximum values of the axial force for translationally moving tools, respectively, for untreated and for already treated surfaces. Each value of F1 and F2 is obtained as mean arithmetic from the measured maximum values for the three specimens from the corresponding point from the factor space. Depending on the length of the treated surface have the functions of the values of the axial forces Fi graphics analogous to that shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Dependence of the axial force on the treated length for translationally moving tool
Table 2.
Experimental design matrix
№ x1 x2 x3 F1, N F2, N q¯1,Nmm q¯2,Nmm
1 1 1 1 28 200 18 050 448.8 287.3

The empirical mathematical models in coded form (that is the factors are in coded form in accordance with equation (14)) for q¯i,i=1,2 are obtained as follows (16)
(17)
as the errors are less than 0.1 per cent.

Equations (16) and (17) have empirical nature since they are obtained by experimental way and regression analysis on the basis of experimental design. They are not obtained by analytical approach on the basis of physical lows. In order to estimate the significance of the governing factors (in this case σY, r¯, εt, 0) as well as the interaction between them, the factors are presented in coded mode (dimensionless) in corresponding regression model in accordance with equation (14). Each factor is changed in the interval - 1 Ĳ xi Ĳ + 1 . Then the coefficients in equations (16) and (17) have the dimension of the function (in this case ‘force/length’), and the absolute values of these coefficients are a measure for the importance of the factors as well as the interaction between them. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) has been conducted by means of QStatLab package in order to estimate in qualitative aspect the factors significance on approximated intensities q¯i of the manufacturing resistance. When the experimental approach for investigation of given process is used, this is generally accepted practice. The main effects of the factors have been shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, the most significant factor is circumferential linear strain x3 and x1 has the least importance. Most greatly expressed is the interaction between the factors x2 and x3 (absolute values of the coefficients are 14.4 and 13.963 ) and the interaction between the three factors has the least significance (0.525 and 2.938 , respectively). With increase of the yield limit x1 of the treated material and the circumferential linear strain x3 both intensities q¯i grow as the influence of x3 is much better. From physical point of view this fact is expected since the increase of x3 leads to increasing the plastically deformed metal volume. The intensities grow with decrease of sizeless radius x2, as the plastic wave height increases. For this reason, the interaction between the factors x2 and x3 is the strongest, since a combination of small radius x2 and large deformation x3 can lead to critical plastic wave (Fig. 6). Fig. 5
Graphics of the main effects of the factors: (a) on the approximated intensity q¯1,N/mm; (b) on the approximated intensity q¯2,N/mm
Fig. 6
Plastic wave obtained from an unsuitable combination: small r¯ and large εt, 0
After substituting (14) in equations (16) and (17) the empirical models for q¯i,i=1,2 in a natural form are obtained
Analysis in details of the influence of the factors onthe process power parameters has been made in section 3.3.

sec.title: 3.3 Investigations of the semi-analytical models obtained
sec.p:
After substitution of equations (16a) and (17a) in the analytical models of the axial force and the rotating moment, respectively (11) and (12), the corresponding semi-analytical models of the SMB power parameters have been obtained (18)
(19)
where Pa is in N; Me is in Nm; dt is in mm; α0 is in rad; q¯i is in N/mm.

Figure 7 shows sections of the hypersurfaces of the models with different planes. The results obtained give reason for the following comments:
The axial force Pa grows with feed f increase at practically constant rate. Although the function Pa = Pa (f) is transcendental, this dependence is, in fact, linear (Fig. 7(a)) because of the small angle θ. The rotating moment Me decreases insignificantly as the feed f increases. In view of the small value of Me, this change has no relevant importance (Fig. 7(d)).
The nominal tightness in affects strongly the axial force Pa (Fig. 7(b)). The latter grows with tightness as in increases. A correlation exists between the factors in and the diameter D0, respectively, dt (see section 3.2.2). For that reason the axial force Pa decreases with diameter D0 increase (Fig. 7(c)) since the circumferential linear strain εt, 0 decreases. When in increases the moment Me sharply increases as the behaviour of the axial force. Unlike the latter, however, the moment Me increases with diameter D0 increase (Fig. 7(f)) because of the presence of dt2 in equation (19).
The higher the yield limit σY of the treated material and the circumferential linear strain εt, 0, the bigger the rotating moment Me and the axial force Pa. The smaller the dimensionless radius r¯, the bigger the rotating moment Me and the axial force Pa on equal other conditions.
With regard to the strength of the manufacturing system, the moment Me takes small values. However, from the point of view of the energy consumed, this moment can not be neglected.
The circumferential linear deformation εt, 0, the tightness in, respectively, has the strongest effect on the axial force Pa and the rotating moment Me. Therefore, εt, 0 is a dominant factor on power parameters of the SMB process.

caption.p: Sections of the axial force Pa and the moment Me hyperfaces with different planes

sec.title: 4 EXPERIMENTAL VERIFICATION OF THE PROPOSED SEMI-ANALYTICAL MODELS
4.1 Experiment formulation
sec.p:
The SMB has been carried out by means of experimental device, shown in reference [16]. A strain gauge transducer has been designed for measuring the axial force Pa of the SMB process (Fig. 8). It is designed with ‘full bridge’ type of circuit as two of the strain gauges are oriented in direction of the force measured and the rest are perpendicular to this force. The transducer can measure a force up to 12,000 N and for this interval its diagram is linear. Fig. 8
Measurement of the axial force: (a) additional device with strain gauge transducer; (b) measuring apparatuses

Constructional medium-carbon steel having yieldlimit σY = 491 MPa has been used to make the burnished specimens. Three values of the parameters εt, 0− 0.005 , 0.0075 , and 0.012 , corresponding to nominal tightness in − 0.1 mm, 0.15 mm, and 0.2 mm, and for two values of the parameter r¯ − 0.2469 and 0.4986 have been taken down for the axial force Pa. The nominal diameter of the tools is dt = 20 mm. The specimen diameters have a tolerance of ± 0.01 mm. The device angle of nutation θ is equal to 2°. The SMB manufacturing parameters are burnishing speed ne = 125 rpm; burnishing feed f = 0.25 mm/rev.

sec.title: 4.2 Experimental results
sec.p:
The outcomes from the experimental determination of the axial force Pa as well as their comparison withthese obtained by the proposed semi-analytical model for the same manufacturing, physical, and geometrical parameters are shown in Fig. 9. Comparison shows a good agreement between the two kinds of results. Fig. 9
Experimental results for the axial force and comparison with the semi-analytical model: (a) r¯=0.4986; (b)r¯=0.2469

The experimental results show the following effect, which cannot be predicted by the semi-analytical model: gradual increase in the axial force Pa along the workpiece axis due to generation of a deformation plastic wave. This effect is considerably more prominent for bigger values of the circumferential linear deformation εt, 0 and for smaller radius r¯ of the toroidal acting part of the tool. Obviously, with regard tostrength and deformation in the machine-device-tool-workpiece system, it is more expedient to use small values of the parameter εt, 0, respectively, small tightness and bigger values of dimesionless radius r¯. Based on the good correlation between the semi-analitical model of the axial force Pa and the relevant experimental results, it is quite possible to conclude that the rotating moment Me model is relevant as well since both are drawn from common physical basis.

list-item.p: A new method of burnishing of external cylindrical surfaces called spherical motion burnishing has been developed. The method has been implemented on lathes.

On the basis of the real tool motion, analytical models of the power parameters of the SMB process have been obtained. The unknown manufacturing intensities in these models have been determined experimentally by means of a planned experiment.

For proving the authenticity of the proposed semi-analytical models, the axial force of the SMB process has been measured by means of a strain gauge system. The comparison of the results from the semi-analytical model for the axial force with experimental outcomes shows a good level of agreement.
The proposed approach to determine the SMB power parameters can be applied to other burnished materials. For that purpose it is necessaryforthe intensities q¯i to be determined experimentally.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This work was supported by the Bulgarian Ministry of Education and Science and the Technical University of Gabrovo [grant number M-920/2009].
